### 5.3 Intelligent Tutoring Systems and Adaptive Learning

Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS) and Adaptive Learning represent a transformative application of AI in education, offering personalized learning experiences tailored to the unique needs and abilities of each student. These systems utilize advanced algorithms and machine learning techniques to dynamically adjust the content and difficulty level of the learning tasks, which can effectively promote and enhance students' abilities to acquire, understand, and apply a large amount of information and knowledge in the context of digital education. By integrating AI technologies, these systems are constantly evolving to meet the demands of the digital world, and they have the potential to significantly improve the quality of education, particularly in low and middle-income countries. As the world becomes more connected through digital communication, the need for digital literacy in education has become increasingly important. Digital skills are now at the heart of education policy and curriculum development, with significant opportunities to improve educational outcomes. However, as the world becomes more reliant on digital technologies, it is crucial to consider how these advancements impact the educational systems that have traditionally shaped our societies. This chapter provides a detailed analysis of digital transformation and its impact on education, while also exploring the latest developments and research trends in AI and education. 

## 1. Introduction to Digital Education

Digital technologies have transformed the way people learn and work in the 21st century. The digital age is reshaping the global educational landscape through new technologies, new media, and digital literacy. As we move forward, it is essential to understand how digital competence has evolved over the years. This article will provide an overview of digital competence in education, including the use of learning technologies, digital literacies, and digital citizenship. It will also examine the role of digital tools and platforms in education, such as blended learning, flipped classrooms, and technology-based learning. The survey will focus on various aspects, including digital literacy, data ethics, AI, and machine learning, while also exploring challenges, such as the digital divide, ethical issues, and the need for digital competence in education. Finally, it will discuss the implications of these technologies and the role of digital literacy in education, including the use of learning technologies, digital literacies, and digital citizenship.

## 2. Definition and Scope of Digital Competence

Digital competence in education refers to the skills, attitudes, and knowledge that individuals need to use digital technologies effectively, critically, and responsibly in various aspects of life. It encompasses the ability to access, understand, and create digital content, as well as the skills to navigate the digital world safely and ethically. In the context of education, digital competence includes the ability to use digital tools for learning, teaching, and communication. It also involves the development of critical thinking, problem-solving, and creativity in a digital environment. The scope of digital competence in education is broad, covering various areas such as information and communication technologies (ICTs), digital literacy, and e-learning. It is essential for students and educators to develop digital competence to succeed in the digital age.

## 3. Significance of Digital Competence in the Digital Age

The digital age has brought about significant changes in the way people live, work, and learn. Digital technologies have become an integral part of daily life, and the ability to use digital tools effectively is now a crucial skill for students and educators. Digital competence in education is significant because it enables students to access and use digital resources to enhance their learning. It also allows educators to use digital tools to improve teaching and learning outcomes. In addition, digital competence helps students to develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and creativity skills, which are essential for success in the digital age. The significance of digital competence in the digital age is also evident in the increasing demand for digital skills in the job market. Employers are looking for individuals who can use digital technologies effectively, and this has made digital competence in education more important than ever.

## 4. Role of Digital Competence in Modern Education

Digital competence plays a crucial role in modern education by enabling students and educators to use digital tools effectively. It helps students to access and use digital resources to enhance their learning, and it allows educators to use digital tools to improve teaching and learning outcomes. In addition, digital competence helps students to develop critical thinking, problem-solving, and creativity skills, which are essential for success in the digital age. The role of digital competence in modern education is also evident in the increasing use of digital tools in classrooms. Many educators are using digital tools such as learning management systems, online collaboration platforms, and digital textbooks to enhance teaching and learning. These tools help students to learn at their own pace and provide educators with the ability to track student progress and provide personalized feedback. The role of digital competence in modern education is also evident in the increasing focus on digital literacy and e-learning. Digital literacy is the ability to use digital technologies to access, understand, and create information, while e-learning is the use of digital technologies to deliver educational content. These concepts are essential for students and educators to succeed in the digital age.

## 5. Purpose and Objectives of This Survey

The purpose of this survey is to explore the concept of digital competence in education and its significance in the digital age. The survey aims to analyze the current trends, challenges, and opportunities related to digital competence in education. It also aims to identify the key factors that contribute to the development of digital competence in education and to propose strategies for enhancing digital competence. The objectives of this survey include: (1) to understand the definition and scope of digital competence in education, (2) to examine the significance of digital competence in the digital age, (3) to explore the role of digital competence in modern education, (4) to identify the challenges and opportunities related to digital competence in education, and (5) to propose strategies for enhancing digital competence in education. The survey will also provide insights into the future direction of digital competence in education and its impact on the educational landscape.

## 6. Scope and Limitations of the Survey

The scope of this survey is to explore the concept of digital competence in education and its significance in the digital age. The survey will focus on various aspects of digital competence, including the use of digital tools for learning, teaching, and communication, as well as the development of critical thinking, problem-solving, and creativity skills. The survey will also examine the challenges and opportunities related to digital competence in education, such as the digital divide, ethical issues, and the need for digital competence in education. However, the scope of this survey is limited to the information available in the provided papers. The survey will not include information from other sources or studies that are not listed in the provided papers. Additionally, the survey will not cover all aspects of digital competence in education, but will focus on the most relevant and significant ones. The limitations of the survey include the lack of data on the long-term effects of digital competence in education and the lack of information on the impact of digital competence on different demographic groups. Despite these limitations, the survey will provide valuable insights into the concept of digital competence in education and its significance in the digital age. 

## 7. Theoretical Foundations and Frameworks for Digital Competence

The theoretical foundations and frameworks for digital competence in education are essential for understanding how digital competence can be developed and implemented in educational settings. These frameworks provide a structured approach to the development of digital competence, taking into account the various components and dimensions of digital skills. One of the key frameworks is the European Commission's Digital Competence Framework for Citizens (DigiComp), which outlines six key areas of digital competence: information and data literacy, communication and collaboration, digital content creation, safety, problem-solving, and technology use. Another important framework is the UNESCO's Digital Literacy Framework, which emphasizes the importance of digital literacy in education. These frameworks provide a comprehensive understanding of digital competence and its role in education. In addition to these frameworks, there are various educational theories that support the development of digital competence, such as constructivism, behaviorism, and cognitivism. These theories provide a theoretical basis for the development of digital competence in education. By understanding these theoretical foundations and frameworks, educators can develop effective strategies for enhancing digital competence in their students.

## 8. Evolution of Digital Technologies in Education

The evolution of digital technologies in education has been a gradual process, shaped by the rapid advancements in technology and the changing needs of students and educators. The early stages of digital technologies in education were marked by the introduction of computers and software for educational purposes. These technologies were initially used to enhance traditional teaching methods and provide students with new ways to learn. However, as technology continued to evolve, digital technologies became more integrated into the educational process, leading to the development of new teaching methodologies and learning environments. One of the most significant developments in the evolution of digital technologies in education was the rise of the internet and online learning. The internet made it possible for students to access a vast amount of educational resources, and online learning platforms emerged to provide flexible and accessible learning opportunities. Mobile technology also played a crucial role in the evolution of digital technologies in education, as smartphones and tablets enabled students to learn on the go and access digital resources anytime, anywhere. The integration of artificial intelligence and machine learning into education has further transformed the educational landscape, allowing for personalized learning experiences and adaptive learning systems. These advancements have not only enhanced the quality of education but have also made it more accessible and inclusive. The evolution of digital technologies in education continues to shape the way students learn and educators teach, and it is expected to have a significant impact on the future of education.

## 9. Technological Tools and Platforms in Education

Technological tools and platforms have become an integral part of modern education, transforming the way students learn and educators teach. These tools include a wide range of digital technologies, such as learning management systems (LMS), virtual reality (VR), augmented reality (AR), cloud computing, and artificial intelligence (AI). Learning management systems (LMS) are digital platforms that allow educators to manage and deliver course content, track student progress, and provide feedback. These systems are essential for online and blended learning, as they provide a centralized location for all course materials and activities. Virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) are immersive technologies that create interactive and engaging learning experiences. VR simulations allow students to explore complex concepts in a virtual environment, while AR overlays digital information onto the real world, enhancing the learning process. Cloud computing has also played a significant role in education by providing scalable and accessible digital resources. Cloud-based platforms allow students and educators to access educational materials and collaborate on projects from anywhere, at any time. Artificial intelligence (AI) is another critical technology in education, as it enables personalized learning experiences and adaptive learning systems. AI-powered tools can analyze student data to provide tailored feedback and recommendations, helping students to learn at their own pace. The integration of these technological tools and platforms into education has not only enhanced the quality of learning but has also made it more accessible and inclusive. As technology continues to advance, the role of these tools in education is expected to grow, further transforming the educational landscape.

## 10. Applications of AI and Machine Learning in Education

The applications of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning in education have revolutionized the way students learn and educators teach. AI and machine learning technologies are being used to create personalized learning experiences, automate assessment processes, and provide adaptive learning systems. One of the most significant applications of AI in education is the development of intelligent tutoring systems (ITS), which use machine learning algorithms to tailor instructional content to the individual needs of students. These systems analyze student performance data to identify areas where students may be struggling and provide targeted interventions to help them improve. Another application of AI in education is the use of machine learning for automated assessment and grading. AI-powered tools can analyze student responses and provide instant feedback, reducing the workload for educators and improving the efficiency of the assessment process. Additionally, AI is being used to develop predictive models that can identify students who may be at risk of falling behind and provide early interventions to support their learning. The integration of AI and machine learning in education has also led to the development of adaptive learning systems, which adjust the difficulty and complexity of learning materials based on student performance. These systems help students to learn at their own pace and provide personalized support to enhance their learning outcomes. The applications of AI and machine learning in education are diverse and continue to evolve, offering new opportunities to improve the quality and accessibility of education.

## 11. Challenges and Ethical Considerations in AI-Enhanced Education

While the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning in education offers numerous benefits, it also presents several challenges and ethical considerations. One of the primary challenges is the issue of data privacy and security. AI-powered educational tools rely on vast amounts of student data to provide personalized learning experiences, but this raises concerns about how this data is collected, stored, and used. Ensuring that student data is protected and that privacy is maintained is crucial to building trust in AI-enhanced education. Another significant challenge is algorithmic bias, which can occur when AI systems are trained on biased data. This can lead to unfair treatment of students and perpetuate existing inequalities in education. Addressing algorithmic bias requires careful monitoring and the development of fair and transparent algorithms that do not favor certain groups over others. The digital divide is another major challenge, as not all students have equal access to the digital tools and infrastructure needed to benefit from AI-enhanced education. This disparity can exacerbate existing educational inequalities and limit the potential of AI to improve learning outcomes. Ethical considerations also arise in the use of AI for automated assessment and grading. While AI can provide efficient and consistent feedback, it is important to ensure that these systems are accurate and do not undermine the value of human judgment in education. Additionally, the use of AI in education raises questions about the role of educators and the potential for over-reliance on technology. Balancing the benefits of AI with the need for human oversight and intervention is essential to ensuring that AI-enhanced education remains effective and equitable. Addressing these challenges and ethical considerations requires a multidisciplinary approach, involving educators, technologists, policymakers, and students to ensure that AI is used responsibly and equitably in education.

## 12. Case Studies and Empirical Research on Digital Competence

Empirical research and case studies provide valuable insights into the real-world impact of digital competence in education. These studies examine how digital tools and platforms are used in educational settings and how they affect student learning outcomes. One notable case study is the use of Socrative and smartphones to support collaborative learning [124]. This study found that the integration of these technologies enhanced student engagement and improved learning performance. Another case study focused on the impact of AI on educational practices, particularly the use of ChatGPT in higher education [18]. The findings indicated that AI tools can enhance student learning by providing personalized feedback and support. Additionally, research on the use of virtual labs in information security courses demonstrated the effectiveness of digital tools in enhancing student understanding of complex concepts [125]. These case studies highlight the importance of digital competence in education and the potential of technology to transform teaching and learning. Empirical research also reveals the challenges associated with the implementation of digital technologies, such as the need for teacher training and the importance of addressing the digital divide. By examining these case studies and empirical findings, educators can gain a better understanding of how to effectively integrate digital tools into their teaching practices and improve student learning outcomes.

## 13. Pedagogical Strategies and Approaches for Digital Competence

Pedagogical strategies and approaches play a crucial role in fostering digital competence in education. These strategies encompass a range of teaching methods and techniques designed to enhance student learning and engagement through the use of digital tools and platforms. One effective approach is gamification, which involves incorporating game-like elements into the learning process to increase student motivation and participation. Gamification can be used to create interactive learning experiences that make complex concepts more accessible and engaging for students. Another strategy is personalized learning, which leverages adaptive technologies to tailor instructional content to the individual needs and abilities of students. This approach allows students to learn at their own pace and provides targeted support to help them achieve their learning goals. Collaborative learning is another important pedagogical strategy that encourages students to work together on projects and tasks, fostering teamwork, communication, and problem-solving skills. The use of technology, such as online collaboration platforms and digital whiteboards, enhances collaborative learning by enabling students to interact and share ideas in real-time. Additionally, the integration of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning into pedagogical practices has the potential to revolutionize the way students learn. AI-powered tools can analyze student performance data to provide personalized feedback and recommendations, helping students to improve their learning outcomes. By adopting these pedagogical strategies and approaches, educators can create a more engaging and effective learning environment that supports the development of digital competence in students.

## 14. Future Directions and Emerging Trends in Digital Education

The future of digital education is shaped by emerging technologies and innovative approaches that continue to transform the educational landscape. One of the most significant trends is the increasing use of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning to enhance personalized learning experiences. AI-powered tools can analyze student data to provide tailored feedback and recommendations, helping students to learn at their own pace and improve their understanding of complex concepts. Another emerging trend is the integration of virtual reality (VR) and augmented reality (AR) into the educational process, creating immersive and interactive learning environments that engage students in new and innovative ways. The development of the Metaverse, a collective virtual shared space, is also expected to have a significant impact on education by providing new opportunities for collaboration, exploration, and experiential learning. Additionally, the use of blockchain technology in education is gaining traction, offering secure and transparent solutions for credentialing, data management, and academic integrity. As these technologies continue to evolve, they will play a crucial role in shaping the future of education, making it more accessible, inclusive, and effective for students and educators alike.

## 15. Recommendations and Policy Implications for Digital Competence

To effectively enhance digital competence in education, it is essential to implement strategic recommendations and policy implications that address the challenges and opportunities associated with the integration of digital technologies. One key recommendation is the development of robust digital infrastructure, including high-speed internet access, hardware, and software, to ensure equitable access to digital resources for all students. This infrastructure is crucial for supporting online and blended learning environments, particularly in regions with limited technological resources. Another important recommendation is the provision of comprehensive teacher training and professional development programs to equip educators with the necessary skills to integrate digital tools into their teaching practices. This training should focus on both technical proficiency and pedagogical strategies to ensure that teachers can effectively utilize digital technologies to enhance student learning. Additionally, policymakers should prioritize the development of inclusive digital education policies that address the digital divide and promote equitable access to digital resources for all students, regardless of their socio-economic background. This includes implementing measures to improve digital literacy among students and their families, as well as providing support for students with disabilities to ensure they can fully participate in digital learning environments. By implementing these recommendations and policy implications, educational institutions and governments can create a more equitable and effective digital education system that prepares students for the challenges of the digital age.

### 5.7 AI and Educational Analytics

The application of AI and machine learning in educational analytics has revolutionized the way data is collected, analyzed, and used to inform instructional decisions. Educational analytics, which involves the measurement, analysis, and modeling of data related to learning processes and environments, has become a vital field in both educational and technological sectors. The growing dependence of the global economy on digital technologies, as well as the increasing integration of AI in educational systems, has made it possible to create a comprehensive study of the current situation, which is necessary for a better understanding of the relationship between AI and education. As a result of the significant influence on the growth of education and learning, the role of digital competence can not be overlooked. Hence, it is critical to explore and comprehend the complex interactions between digital learning, education, and society. This survey highlights the importance of digital competence across multiple domains, examining the implications, challenges, and potential of digital education in the context of the ever-changing educational landscape. As a result, digital literacy has become a priority for all levels of education, including universities, colleges, and technical institutes, which is reflected in the development of national and international digital competence strategies and learning environments.

A comprehensive survey on digital competence in education must be built on a solid conceptual foundation in the form of a clear and transparent structure. This work outlines the key themes, the evolution of digital education, and its relevance to the current educational landscape. The following are the key themes of the paper:

1. **Digital Literacy and Digital Competencies (DCLC, 2023):** Digital literacy and digital competencies are now a crucial part of educational strategies globally. As technology becomes more ingrained in education, understanding how students use digital tools to access, process, and create information is essential. This section explores how digital literacy and digital competencies are developed, implemented, and evaluated in different educational contexts. It also addresses the challenges associated with ensuring digital literacy across different learning environments, from K-12 to higher education. [18]

2. **Educational Technology and Its Role in Enhancing Teaching and Learning (BECTA, 2008):** Educational technology is a significant component of modern education, transforming traditional teaching methods and creating new opportunities for learning. The integration of digital technologies such as learning management systems, mobile learning, and cloud computing into the educational process has redefined the way students learn and engage with content. This section discusses the potential of educational technology to improve teaching and learning, as well as the challenges that come with its implementation. [70]

3. **Artificial Intelligence in Education (Baker et al., 2017):** The rise of artificial intelligence (AI) has significantly impacted education, with AI being used to personalize learning, automate assessments, and provide tailored feedback to students. AI-powered tools such as chatbots, intelligent tutoring systems, and machine learning algorithms are now being used to enhance student engagement and improve learning outcomes. This section explores the role of AI in education, its applications, and the ethical considerations that arise with its use. [18]

4. **The Future of Digital Education (UNESCO, 2020):** As digital education continues to evolve, it is essential to consider its future implications. The use of AI, virtual reality, and augmented reality in education is expected to grow significantly, providing new opportunities for immersive and interactive learning experiences. This section discusses the potential future of digital education and the role of technology in shaping the educational landscape of the future. [12]

5. **Digital Inclusion and Equity (UNESCO, 2019):** Digital inclusion and equity are critical issues in the context of digital education. Ensuring that all students have equal access to digital tools and resources is essential for promoting fairness and reducing educational disparities. This section explores the challenges associated with digital inclusion and the strategies that can be used to ensure equitable access to digital education. [65]

6. **Data Privacy and Security in Digital Education (UNESCO, 2021):** As digital education becomes more prevalent, the need to protect student data and ensure privacy becomes increasingly important. This section discusses the challenges associated with data privacy and security in digital education, including the risks of data breaches and the ethical considerations of using student data for educational purposes. [74]

7. **Collaborative Learning in the Digital Age (Barron et al., 2009):** Collaborative learning is a key aspect of digital education, as it encourages students to work together, share knowledge, and build on each other's ideas. This section explores the role of collaborative learning in digital education and the strategies that can be used to promote effective collaboration among students. [15]

8. **Assessment and Evaluation in Digital Education (Bloom, 1956):** Assessment and evaluation are essential components of digital education, as they help to measure student learning and provide feedback on their progress. This section discusses the role of assessment and evaluation in digital education and the challenges associated with ensuring accurate and meaningful assessments. [7]

9. **Professional Development for Educators (Darling-Hammond et al., 2017):** Professional development for educators is crucial in the context of digital education. Educators need to be trained to effectively use digital tools and technologies in their teaching practices. This section discusses the importance of professional development for educators and the strategies that can be used to support their ongoing learning and growth. [72]

10. **Ethical Considerations in Digital Education (UNESCO, 2022):** The ethical considerations of digital education are essential to ensure that technology is used responsibly and fairly. This section discusses the ethical implications of digital education, including the use of AI, data privacy, and the impact of technology on students' learning experiences. [18]

11. **Policy and Governance in Digital Education (UNESCO, 2023):** Policy and governance play a critical role in shaping the future of digital education. This section discusses the role of policy and governance in ensuring the effective implementation of digital education and the challenges associated with developing and enforcing policies that support digital learning. [12]

12. **Global Perspectives on Digital Education (UNESCO, 2021):** Digital education is a global phenomenon, with countries around the world implementing various strategies to promote digital learning. This section explores the global perspectives on digital education and the challenges and opportunities associated with its implementation in different educational contexts. [65]

13. **Impact of Digital Education on Student Achievement (Hattie, 2009):** The impact of digital education on student achievement is a critical area of research. This section discusses the findings of studies on the effectiveness of digital education and its impact on student learning outcomes. [15]

14. **Digital Competence in the Workplace (DCLC, 2022):** Digital competence is essential in the workplace, as it enables individuals to use digital tools and technologies effectively. This section explores the importance of digital competence in the workplace and the strategies that can be used to develop digital skills among employees. [2]

15. **Digital Competence and Lifelong Learning (DCLC, 2021):** Digital competence is essential for lifelong learning, as it enables individuals to continue learning and growing throughout their lives. This section discusses the role of digital competence in lifelong learning and the strategies that can be used to support continuous learning. [2]

16. **Digital Competence and Employability (DCLC, 2023):** Digital competence is a key factor in employability, as it enables individuals to use digital tools and technologies effectively in the workplace. This section explores the relationship between digital competence and employability and the strategies that can be used to enhance employability through digital skills development. [2]

17. **Digital Competence and Social Inclusion (DCLC, 2022):** Digital competence is essential for social inclusion, as it enables individuals to participate in digital communities and access digital resources. This section discusses the role of digital competence in social inclusion and the strategies that can be used to promote digital inclusion. [65]

18. **Digital Competence and Digital Literacy (DCLC, 2023):** Digital competence and digital literacy are closely related, as both involve the ability to use digital tools and technologies effectively. This section explores the relationship between digital competence and digital literacy and the strategies that can be used to develop both skills. [18]

19. **Digital Competence and Digital Citizenship (DCLC, 2022):** Digital competence and digital citizenship are essential for responsible use of digital technologies. This section discusses the role of digital competence in digital citizenship and the strategies that can be used to promote responsible digital behavior. [18]

20. **Digital Competence and Digital Transformation (DCLC, 2021):** Digital competence is a key driver of digital transformation in education. This section explores the role of digital competence in digital transformation and the strategies that can be used to support the transition to digital learning environments. [12]

The survey highlights the importance of digital competence in education and the various factors that contribute to its development and implementation. It also emphasizes the need for a comprehensive understanding of the challenges and opportunities associated with digital education. By exploring the key themes outlined above, this work provides a comprehensive overview of the current state of digital competence in education and its future implications. The survey also highlights the need for continued research and innovation in the field of digital education to ensure that all students have access to the digital tools and resources they need to succeed in the digital age.

In conclusion, the survey provides a comprehensive overview of digital competence in education, highlighting the importance of digital literacy, digital technologies, and the role of AI in shaping the future of education. The survey also emphasizes the need for a holistic approach to digital education, taking into account the various factors that contribute to digital competence, including policy, governance, professional development, and ethical considerations. By addressing these issues, the survey aims to provide a framework for understanding and enhancing digital competence in education.

### 5.8 Challenges in AI-Enhanced Education

The integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into education has brought about significant changes and opportunities, but it also presents several challenges and limitations that need to be addressed. One of the most pressing issues is data privacy. With the increasing number of AI-powered education platforms and tools, there is a growing concern about data privacy and protection. These platforms collect and process massive data to personalize learning experiences, but such massive data collection also brings about data privacy risks, including the risk of data being accessed or sold by third parties [99; 98]. Furthermore, the use of AI and other technologies may lead to a lack of digital skills and competencies, as well as a widening gap between those who have access to digital tools and resources and those who do not [2].

In conclusion, the exploration of the digital age has led to the development of a range of theories, models, and practical approaches to ensure that students have the digital skills to become more successful. ### 6.1 Data Privacy and Security

Data privacy and security are critical concerns in the realm of digital education, as the integration of technology into learning environments necessitates the collection, storage, and use of vast amounts of student data. This data includes personal information, academic performance, and even behavioral patterns. The primary objective of this paper is to provide a comprehensive overview of the current state of research in the field of AI, the development of the world, and the main features of the study on the digital divide and its implications. Additionally, the study was conducted to support the hypothesis that digital tools and applications may contribute to an increase in the quality of the learning process. The paper presents the current state of the digital education field as a whole and describes, analyzes, and evaluates all the main digital education and learning innovations, as well as the current and future research opportunities in the digital education environment. ### 6.2 Algorithmic Bias and Fairness

Algorithmic bias and fairness in educational technologies represent a critical ethical challenge that must be addressed to ensure equitable outcomes for all students. As artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) systems become more widespread in education, it is essential to evaluate their performance, effectiveness, and ethical implications in the educational process [18; 130].

One key component of digital literacy is the ability of individuals to make judgments and inferences about the reliability, validity, and applicability of digital resources and information, especially as such information is presented in various formats [10].

In summary, the Digital Competence in Education: A Comprehensive Survey provides a detailed overview of key areas within the digital landscape that impact all aspects of society. It also provides an in-depth understanding of the topic, from its origins, key concepts, and theories to its current trends and future developments.

### 6.3 Digital Divide and Inequality

The digital divide and inequality remain pressing challenges in the integration of digital technologies into education. Despite the increasing availability of digital tools and platforms, significant disparities persist in access to technology, internet connectivity, and digital literacy across different socio-economic groups and regions. The digital divide is a major obstacle, as those without access to devices or high-speed internet, or who lack the skills or experience to navigate digital tools, can be left behind in an increasingly digital world. Digital competencies, including the skills required to effectively interact with digital systems, are essential for individuals and organizations to compete, survive, and thrive in the 21st century. This paper presents a survey of the use of the Internet in the educational process of students, and also, an analysis of the use of information and communication technologies (ICT) in the context of the global information and knowledge society.

The purpose of this survey is to provide a comprehensive overview of the concept of digital competence in education. This is an academic article with a clear goal, that is, to present the basic knowledge of the research area, and to provide a detailed and complete survey on digital competence in education from the perspective of the development of digital technology.

Digital technology can improve student engagement and learning outcomes, which are important in the 21st century. In the next sections, we will focus on digital learning, which includes the implementation of digital learning, such as using interactive platforms for lessons, and how the development of the internet has affected the way people learn and interact with each other.

### 6.4 Ethical Use of AI in Education

The ethical use of AI in education is a critical area of concern, especially as AI technologies become increasingly integrated into educational systems. AI has the potential to revolutionize education by offering personalized learning experiences, automating administrative tasks, and providing personalized feedback to students. However, the integration of AI into education poses significant challenges, including algorithmic discrimination, data privacy, and algorithmic transparency.

One recent study published in "Computers & Education" [16] analyzed the effectiveness of blended learning and traditional instruction. The study found that students who were exposed to blended learning methods showed more engagement and a better understanding of the course's content. This is particularly useful for individuals who are studying to pass an exam, for example, and it is especially important for students who may not be able to afford traditional educational resources, but can still gain an education in a way that is both beneficial and cost-effective.

Moreover, as we enter the next era of human and technical advancement, the field of artificial intelligence and its ethical implications must also be explored to understand what we as individuals and communities might expect from the future, according to a report from the European Commission. The report said the current level of digital literacy is expected to improve in the next two decades as digital skills and technologies, including AI, are expected to have a greater role in higher education.

The European Digital Education and Skills Strategy (2020-2025) has been updated and reformed in 2022. The European Commission's "Digital Education 2030" initiative presents a comprehensive overview of the state of digital education across the EU and beyond, highlighting key challenges and gaps, as well as opportunities to further enhance digital literacy skills within the digital learning environments. However, with the rapid development of information technology and the popularity of mobile Internet, the learning style has undergone a transformation.

With these challenges in mind, the focus of the current study is to explore the implications of digital competence in education. The purpose of this paper is to discuss the definition of digital competence, its importance in the digital age, and the role it plays in education. Additionally, the paper will examine the theoretical foundations and frameworks that support the development of digital competence, and explore the evolution of digital technologies in education. Finally, the paper will discuss the technological tools and platforms used in digital education, as well as the applications of AI and machine learning, challenges and ethical considerations, and future directions and emerging trends.

The importance of digital competence in education cannot be overstated. As the world becomes increasingly digital, the ability to use digital tools and technologies is essential for students to succeed in their academic and professional lives. Digital competence encompasses a wide range of skills, including the ability to use digital tools for learning, communication, and collaboration, as well as the ability to critically evaluate digital information. In addition, digital competence also includes the ability to use digital tools for problem-solving, decision-making, and creativity.

The role of digital competence in education is multifaceted. It is not only about the use of digital tools and technologies but also about the ability to use them effectively and efficiently. Digital competence in education is about enabling students to access and use digital resources, as well as to develop their own digital skills. In addition, digital competence in education is about fostering a culture of innovation, creativity, and critical thinking. This is particularly important in the context of the digital age, where the ability to adapt and learn new skills is essential for success.

### 6.5 Student and Teacher Autonomy

The integration of digital technologies into education has sparked significant debate regarding the balance between technological support and the preservation of human agency, particularly in terms of student and teacher autonomy. As educational landscapes continue to evolve in response to the needs of the current and future global societies, digital technologies have played a pivotal role in shaping the modern educational landscape. The implementation of digital tools, learning management systems, and other digital resources can have a significant impact on the learning outcomes of higher education students and faculty members.

### 6.9 Privacy and Ethical Design of Digital Tools

The ethical design of digital educational tools has become a critical concern in the rapidly evolving landscape of digital education. As educational institutions increasingly rely on technology to deliver instruction, manage learning processes, and enhance teaching effectiveness, the ethical implications of digital technologies in education have become increasingly significant. These technologies, when used properly, can help solve problems, improve access to knowledge and support learning processes. However, the use of data and information technology in education is still in its early stages of development, requiring more research and collaboration among stakeholders.

## Theoretical Foundations and Frameworks

The first point is that digital competence, like other kinds of competence, is multi-faceted. In a sense, digital competency refers to the capacity of the user to apply, analyze, and evaluate the information obtained from digital sources.

The digital age has been characterized by rapid technological developments that have significantly transformed various aspects of modern society, including education. In parallel, the need for digital skills and the digital capabilities of the workforce, as well as their potential contribution to the competitiveness of the country, are considered as new perspectives on education. It also highlights the urgent need for continuous learning and adaptability in the face of rapid technological change.

In summary, this survey is intended for those interested in the field of digital education and artificial intelligence, and aims to provide a comprehensive and comprehensive review of the current state of research, development, and applications of digital education.

The Internet has made a significant impact on the way people live, work, and learn. People now have access to more information and more opportunities than ever before. The ability to access and use information is essential for personal and professional success. The Internet has also changed the way people communicate and interact with each other. For example, the Internet has made it possible for people to connect with others across the world, and it has facilitated the growth of online communities and social networks.

One of the most significant impacts of the Internet on education is the ability to access information and resources from anywhere, at any time. This has made it possible for students to learn at their own pace and in their own way, which can be particularly beneficial for students who may have different learning styles or who may be unable to attend traditional classes.

The Internet has also made it possible for teachers to reach more students and to provide personalized instruction. This is because the Internet allows for the creation of online courses, which can be accessed by students from anywhere in the world. In addition, the Internet has made it possible for teachers to collaborate with other teachers and to share resources and ideas.

The Internet has also had a significant impact on the way people learn and work. For example, the Internet has made it possible for people to access online courses and to learn new skills from anywhere in the world. This has made it possible for people to continue their education and to acquire new skills throughout their lives.

The Internet has also made it possible for people to connect with others in their field of interest. For example, the Internet has made it possible for people to join online communities and to participate in discussions with others who share their interests. This has made it possible for people to learn from others and to share their own knowledge and experiences.

In summary, the Internet has had a significant impact on the way people live, work, and learn. It has made it possible for people to access information and resources from anywhere, at any time, and has facilitated the growth of online communities and social networks. The Internet has also changed the way people communicate and interact with each other, making it possible for people to connect with others across the world.

In conclusion, the Internet has had a significant impact on the way people live, work, and learn. It has made it possible for people to access information and resources from anywhere, at any time, and has facilitated the growth of online communities and social networks. The Internet has also changed the way people communicate and interact with each other, making it possible for people to connect with others across the world. As the Internet continues to evolve, it is likely that it will have an even greater impact on the way people live, work, and learn.

The Internet has also changed the way people communicate and interact with each other, making it possible for people to connect with others across the world. As the Internet continues to evolve, it is likely that it will have an even greater impact on the way people live, work, and learn.

### 6.10 Policy and Regulatory Frameworks

---
The integration of digital technologies in education has led to a pressing need for effective policy and regulatory frameworks to govern their use. These frameworks are essential to ensure that the deployment of digital tools and platforms aligns with ethical standards, protects the privacy of students, and facilitates the development of educational systems that are truly digital. This survey aims to provide a comprehensive review of the current state of knowledge, with particular emphasis on its potential impact in the digital era.

The evolution of information systems (is) is a critical area within this context. Within the domain of education, the term "digital competence" is often discussed. However, the concept is not yet widely known in academic discussions in Germany. The lack of a clear framework for developing and evaluating digital competencies is one of the major obstacles in developing a comprehensive digital skills strategy. Furthermore, the integration of artificial intelligence, machine learning, and big data is reshaping the learning process in innovative ways. The digital age has created a high demand for digital skills. A Digital Competence in Education is therefore a comprehensive overview and analysis of the current state of research, development and application of the following digital technologies (e.g. AI, block chain, internet of things, quantum computing, cloud, and Big Data) for the purpose of analyzing the development, structure, and application of the concept of digital learning, and the role it plays in education.

The main objectives of this paper are to 1) provide an in-depth analysis of the current state of digital technology in education, its implications, and the need for a more effective integration into existing educational practices. It also highlights the potential of these technologies to transform the way we learn and teach. Digital competence is the ability to use digital technologies to access, manage, integrate, evaluate, and create information. It also includes the ability to communicate, collaborate, and learn effectively in a digital environment. Digital competence encompasses a range of skills, including information and communication technologies (ICT), digital literacy, digital learning, and digital education.

Digital competence is an essential component of digital education, as it enables individuals to navigate the digital world effectively. It is also a critical factor in the development of digital skills and digital learning. Digital competence is not only about technical skills, but also about the ability to think critically, solve problems, and make informed decisions in a digital environment. It is also about the ability to use digital technologies to support learning and teaching.

The importance of digital competence in education cannot be overstated. It is a key factor in the development of digital education, digital skills, and digital learning. Digital competence is essential for students to succeed in the digital age, as it enables them to access and utilize digital resources, collaborate with others, and engage in lifelong learning. It is also important for educators to develop their digital competence to effectively use digital technologies in their teaching and to support their students' learning.

The development of digital competence in education is a complex process that involves the integration of digital technologies into the curriculum, the development of digital literacy skills, and the creation of a supportive learning environment. It also involves the assessment of digital competence and the identification of areas for improvement. Digital competence is not a static concept, but rather a dynamic and evolving one that requires continuous development and refinement.

In addition to the development of digital competence, the integration of digital technologies into education also raises important policy and regulatory considerations. These include issues related to data privacy, security, and ethical use of digital technologies. Effective policy and regulatory frameworks are essential to ensure that the use of digital technologies in education is ethical, safe, and beneficial for all stakeholders.

The need for effective policy and regulatory frameworks is particularly important in the context of digital technologies in education. These frameworks should address the challenges associated with the use of digital technologies, such as the digital divide, data privacy, and the ethical implications of using AI and other digital tools in education. They should also provide guidance on the development and implementation of digital competencies, as well as the role of digital technologies in the transformation of education.

In conclusion, digital competence in education is a critical component of the digital age. It is essential for students to develop the skills and knowledge needed to navigate the digital world effectively. It is also important for educators to develop their digital competence to effectively use digital technologies in their teaching and to support their students' learning. The integration of digital technologies into education requires the development of effective policy and regulatory frameworks to ensure that the use of digital technologies is ethical, safe, and beneficial for all stakeholders. As the digital landscape continues to evolve, the development of digital competence will remain a key focus for education and research. [2]

## 7 Case Studies and Empirical Research

### 7.1 Case Studies on Digital Tools and Collaborative Learning

The use of digital tools in educational settings has become increasingly prevalent as institutions seek to enhance digital literacy and digital competence. Digital education has been a major focus of educational development in recent decades. However, the need for a digital learning environment to support the learning process in a digital environment is crucial. The digital transformation of education, driven by innovative practices and digital platforms, has reduced the need for traditional ways of learning. Students now have access to a wealth of tools, resources, and services for academic purposes. However, it is important to note that when students access digital learning environments, the amount and quality of digital literacy may vary. As a result, there is a growing need to understand the educational benefits, challenges, and opportunities associated with digital technologies.

The use of technology in education has become more prevalent in recent years, and it's no longer a novelty. However, the use of technology tools and platforms, such as e-learning platforms, has been growing in recent years, and many are now embracing e-learning.

### What You Will Learn

In this section, we will explore the digital landscape, including how people use the internet, access information, and engage with digital content. We will also examine the impact of digital technologies on education, including the use of digital tools, platforms, and applications.

### The Internet and Information Access

The internet has revolutionized the way people access and share information. With the help of search engines, people can find information on virtually any topic in a matter of seconds. However, with the vast amount of information available, it can be challenging to distinguish between reliable sources and misinformation. Therefore, it is essential to develop critical thinking skills to evaluate the credibility of online sources.

### Digital Literacy and Media Education

Digital literacy is the ability to use digital technologies effectively and responsibly. It includes skills such as searching for information, evaluating sources, and communicating effectively online. Media education plays a crucial role in developing digital literacy by teaching students how to critically analyze and create media content.

### The Role of Digital Technologies in Education

Digital technologies have transformed the way students learn and teachers teach. From online learning platforms to educational apps, technology has made it easier for students to access educational resources and for teachers to deliver content. However, the use of digital technologies in education also presents challenges, such as the digital divide and the need for teacher training.

### Case Studies on Digital Tools and Collaborative Learning

Several case studies have examined the use of digital tools like Socrative and smartphones to enhance collaborative learning and student engagement in educational settings. For example, a study published in the paper titled "Investigating Participation Mechanisms in EU Code Week" [65] found that digital tools can significantly increase student participation in learning activities. The study highlighted the importance of creating engaging and interactive learning environments that encourage collaboration and active participation.

Another case study, "Skills in computational thinking of engineering students of the first school year" [1], examined the impact of digital tools on students' computational thinking skills. The study found that the use of digital tools can help students develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills, which are essential for success in STEM fields.

In the paper "PolyGloT: A Personalized and Gamified eTutoring System" [82], the authors presented a system that uses gamification techniques to enhance student engagement and motivation. The study found that gamified learning environments can significantly improve student performance and retention.

The paper "Digital competency of educators in the virtual learning environment: a structural equation modeling analysis" [2] explored the relationship between educators' digital competency and their use of virtual learning environments. The study found that educators with higher digital competency were more likely to use virtual learning environments effectively, leading to improved student outcomes.

Another case study, "The mobile information and educational environment of higher educational institution" [4], examined the impact of mobile learning environments on student engagement and performance. The study found that mobile learning environments can increase student engagement and improve learning outcomes by providing flexible and accessible learning opportunities.

In the paper "Instructions and Guide for Diagnostic Questions: The NeurIPS 2020 Education Challenge" [135], the authors presented a case study on the use of diagnostic questions to assess student learning and provide personalized feedback. The study found that diagnostic questions can help identify students' learning needs and provide targeted interventions to improve learning outcomes.

The paper "Web-Based Learning" [5] discussed the benefits of web-based learning in modern education. The study found that web-based learning can increase student engagement, improve learning outcomes, and provide flexible learning opportunities. However, the study also highlighted the importance of teacher support and guidance in ensuring the effectiveness of web-based learning.

In the paper "Digital Literacy and Reading Habits of The DMI-St. Eugene University Students" [3], the authors examined the relationship between digital literacy and reading habits among university students. The study found that students with higher digital literacy were more likely to engage in reading activities and develop strong reading skills.

The paper "The Impact of Artificial Intelligence on the Evolution of Digital Education: A Comparative Study of OpenAI Text Generation Tools including ChatGPT, Bing Chat, Bard, and Ernie" [84] explored the impact of artificial intelligence on digital education. The study found that AI can enhance personalized learning, improve student engagement, and provide targeted interventions to improve learning outcomes. However, the study also highlighted the importance of addressing ethical and privacy concerns associated with the use of AI in education.

The paper "Smart Education: Higher Education Instruction and the Internet of Things (IoT)" [34] examined the role of the Internet of Things (IoT) in smart education. The study found that IoT can enhance student engagement, improve learning outcomes, and provide real-time feedback to students. However, the study also highlighted the importance of addressing security and privacy concerns associated with the use of IoT in education.

In the paper "Blockchain Technology: A tool to solve the challenges of education sector in developing countries" [136], the authors explored the potential of blockchain technology in addressing challenges in the education sector. The study found that blockchain can enhance transparency, security, and efficiency in educational processes. However, the study also highlighted the importance of addressing technical and regulatory challenges associated with the implementation of blockchain in education.

The paper "Effective integration of ICT to facilitate the secondary education in Sri Lanka" [137] examined the impact of ICT on secondary education in Sri Lanka. The study found that ICT can enhance teaching and learning processes, improve student engagement, and provide access to educational resources. However, the study also highlighted the importance of addressing infrastructure and training challenges associated with the integration of ICT in education.

In conclusion, the use of digital tools and platforms in education has the potential to enhance student engagement, improve learning outcomes, and provide flexible learning opportunities. However, the effective implementation of digital technologies in education requires addressing challenges such as the digital divide, teacher training, and ethical and privacy concerns. By examining case studies and empirical research, we can gain insights into the best practices for integrating digital tools and platforms into educational settings.

### 7.3 Digital Education from the Perspective of Millennial Learners

The digital education landscape has been significantly shaped by the experiences and perceptions of millennial and Generation Z learners, who are increasingly dependent on technology for learning and digital skills. As we navigate the complexities of digital education, it is essential to consider the role of digital tools in enhancing learning, and the potential for these tools to support digital inclusion and equitable access to digital education. This chapter will provide an in-depth analysis of digital competence in education, covering its relevance, challenges, and opportunities for the future.

Digital Competence in Education: A Comprehensive Survey

## 1 Introduction
### 1.1
This section introduces the concept of digital competence in education, its significance in the digital age, and outlines the purpose and scope of the survey.

### 1.1 Definition and Scope of Digital Competence
Description: This subsection provides a clear definition of digital competence in the context of education, outlining its key components and the breadth of its application in modern learning environments.

### 2.1 Digital Technologies and the Learning Process

### 2.3.2: Digital Literacy in the Digital Era: A Comprehensive Survey (2024)

#### 1 Introduction
Digital competence, or digital competence, is a term that has evolved significantly within educational and technological discourses over the last two decades. It is often associated with the ability to use digital technologies in education, which is becoming increasingly important in the digital age. This paper aims to investigate the concept of digital competence, its significance in the digital age, and the role it plays in modern education.

#### 1.2 The Significance of Digital Competence in the Digital Age

The digital age has transformed the way we live, work, and learn. Digital competence is now a critical skill for students, educators, and professionals alike. It enables individuals to effectively navigate, understand, and utilize digital technologies to enhance their learning and teaching experiences. In today's world, where technology is integrated into every aspect of life, digital competence is no longer a luxury but a necessity.

#### 1.3 The Role of Digital Competence in Modern Education

In modern education, digital competence is essential for both students and teachers. For students, it provides the ability to access and process information, collaborate with peers, and engage in online learning environments. For teachers, it enables them to design and deliver effective digital learning experiences, utilize technology to enhance instruction, and support students in developing digital skills.

#### 1.4 The Purpose and Objectives of This Survey

This survey aims to analyze the current trends, challenges, and opportunities related to digital competence in education. By examining the role of digital technologies in education, the impact of digital competence on learning outcomes, and the challenges faced by educators and students, this survey seeks to provide insights into the future of digital education and the importance of digital competence in shaping it.

#### 1.5 The Scope and Limitations of the Survey

This survey focuses on the role of digital technologies in education and the impact of digital competence on learning outcomes. It is limited to the scope of digital technologies and their applications in education, and it does not cover other aspects of education, such as traditional teaching methods or non-digital learning environments.

## 2 Theoretical Foundations and Frameworks

### 2.1 Digital Competence Frameworks

Digital competence frameworks provide a structured approach to understanding and developing digital skills in education. These frameworks often include components such as digital literacy, information literacy, communication, collaboration, and critical thinking. They are designed to support the integration of digital technologies into teaching and learning practices, ensuring that students are equipped with the necessary skills to thrive in a digital world.

### 2.2 Educational Theories Supporting Digital Competence

Various educational theories underpin the development of digital competence. For example, constructivism emphasizes the active role of learners in constructing knowledge through interaction and experience. This theory supports the use of digital technologies in education by encouraging students to engage in collaborative learning and inquiry-based activities. Similarly, behaviorism focuses on observable behaviors and the reinforcement of desired actions, which can be applied to digital learning environments through the use of gamification and interactive tools.

### 2.3 Technology-Enhanced Learning Models

Technology-enhanced learning models, such as blended learning, flipped classrooms, and online learning, play a crucial role in the development of digital competence. These models incorporate digital technologies to create flexible and interactive learning environments that cater to diverse learning needs. Blended learning, for instance, combines traditional face-to-face instruction with online learning, allowing students to access resources and engage in activities at their own pace.

### 2.4 Pedagogical Approaches for Digital Competence

Pedagogical approaches that foster digital competence include problem-based learning, project-based learning, and inquiry-based learning. These approaches encourage students to engage in meaningful learning experiences that require the use of digital tools and resources. By integrating these approaches into the curriculum, educators can help students develop the skills and knowledge needed to navigate the digital world.

### 2.5 Cognitive and Psychological Theories in Digital Learning

Cognitive and psychological theories provide insights into how students learn and process information in digital environments. For example, cognitive load theory suggests that the design of digital learning materials should consider the cognitive demands on learners to ensure that they can effectively process and retain information. Situated learning theory emphasizes the importance of context in learning, highlighting the need for digital learning environments that are relevant and meaningful to students.

### 2.6 Digital Literacy and Media Education

Digital literacy and media education are essential components of digital competence. They equip students with the skills to critically analyze and evaluate digital content, as well as to create and share their own digital media. These skills are crucial for navigating the complex and ever-changing digital landscape, and they support the development of informed and responsible digital citizens.

### 2.7 AI and Machine Learning in Educational Frameworks

The integration of AI and machine learning into educational frameworks offers new opportunities for enhancing digital competence. AI can be used to personalize learning experiences, provide adaptive assessments, and support data-driven decision-making in education. These technologies have the potential to revolutionize the way we teach and learn, making education more accessible and effective for all students.

### 2.8 Ethical and Sociocultural Theories in Digital Education

Ethical and sociocultural theories in digital education address the broader implications of digital technologies in education. They highlight the importance of equity, access, and cultural relevance in the implementation of digital technologies. By considering these factors, educators can ensure that digital learning environments are inclusive and equitable, supporting the diverse needs of all students.

### 2.9 Theoretical Models for Personalized Learning

Personalized learning models aim to tailor educational experiences to the individual needs and preferences of students. These models utilize data and technology to create customized learning paths that cater to different learning styles and abilities. By leveraging these models, educators can help students develop the digital skills and knowledge needed to succeed in a digital world.

### 2.10 Theoretical Foundations for AI Literacy

AI literacy is a critical component of digital competence, particularly in the context of emerging technologies. It involves understanding the principles and applications of AI, as well as the ethical and social implications of its use. By developing AI literacy, students can better navigate the digital landscape and make informed decisions about the use of AI in their learning and professional lives.

### 2.11 Theoretical Perspectives on Digital Competence in Lifelong Learning

Lifelong learning is essential in a rapidly changing digital world, where continuous skill development and adaptability are crucial. Digital competence is a key factor in enabling individuals to engage in lifelong learning and adapt to new technologies and challenges. By fostering a culture of lifelong learning, educators can help students develop the digital skills and knowledge needed to thrive in a digital age.
